item.title: Biden sidesteps hard truths in rare primetime address
item.description: Left unsaid in his TV address was the reality that he resigned because it was becoming increasingly clear he would lose to Donald Trump.

item.title: US Lawmaker Hold Ups "War Criminal" Sign During Netanyahu's Congress Speech
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's address to a joint session of the US Congress on Wednesday sparked controversy and division among lawmakers and US citizens.

item.title: What Donald Trump Said On Joe Biden's First Speech After Exiting US Polls
item.description: Joe Biden made his first televised address today since quitting the 2024 US presidential elections earlier this week.

item.title: New Footage Shows US Officers Standing Over Body Of Trump Shooter
item.description: Soon after the attempted assassination of Donald Trump, local law enforcement officers and a U.S. Secret Service agent discussed how pictures of the shooter were shared among officers by a sniper who lost sight of him before he opened fire.

item.title: Protests Against Netanyahu Outside US Capitol, Calls For Gaza Ceasefire
item.description: Thousands gathered in Washington on Wednesday to protest Benjamin Netanyahu and call for a ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas war, as the Israeli premier prepared to address the US Congress.

item.title: 'Our nation needs your leadership once again': Harris at a historically Black sorority
Read a transcript of Biden’s speech on dropping out of the presidential race
item.description:
‘I’ve decided the best way forward is to pass the torch to a new generation,’ Biden said in a speech from the Oval Office

Joe Biden has explained his decision to drop out of the presidential race, saying it was the “best way to unite our nation”.

The US president’s remarks were broadcast from the Oval Office, his first televised appearance since announcing he would end his bid for re-election, and conveyed a reflective and hopeful message.

My fellow Americans, I’m speaking to you tonight from behind the resolute desk in the Oval Office. In this sacred space, I’m surrounded by portraits of extraordinary American presidents.

Thomas Jefferson wrote the immortal words that guide this nation. George Washington showed us presidents are not kings. Abraham Lincoln, who implored us to reject malice. Franklin Roosevelt, who inspired us to reject fear.

Continue reading...
